description: Examination of sociocultural 'registers' of language namely linguistic varieties specific to particular social practices and institutions. Topics include registers of scientific language, religious language, professional language (as in law, bureaucracy, medicine or business), formal and etiquette-laden speech, magical incantation, secret languages, thieves' argot, standardized 'national' languages, and slang. The emphasis throughout is on the relationship between particular linguistic registers and the forms of social life they enable, including forms of social conduct, stereotypes of personhood and group-relative identity, and relations of power and authority between social groups.
name: REGISTERS OF LANGUAGE
